title: The Honor 8 is one of the best phones I've ever had

thread.text: Is probably one of the best I've ever had! I've only had it for two or three days so far but man is it good. I decided to get a smaller phone (came from Moto x style). Everything about this phone feels so nice! I was a little hesitant because of the software but once I booted it up I was very relieved. I'm running nova launcher on it now but I've had no stutters or hiccups or anything. Battery life after a few days has been really solid too, I've made it a full day with heavy use. Love this phone so far.

Couldn't agree more, may I suggest giving EMUI a solid shot. I ran nova and KLWP on every android phone. I have yet to want use it. If it's an app drawer you seek that is coming in February with EMUI 5.0
There are just so many useful features built into the UI. I recommend downloading the user manual and giving it a read through. You will be surprised at the things packed into this amazing device. 
There are communities dedicated to theming EMUI, which changes almost every aspect of EMUI. There are apps to build you own theme using different pieces from other themes, or you can create you own. You can even use your icon packs from the play store. 
I can go on and on about this device haha. Congrats on the phone and there are some good people in this forum. Don't be afraid to ask any questions.

replies.text:
Well size-wise the honor 8 will be no comparison there.
As far as quality, feel and speed it's most definitely a major go!
I would call the honor 8 a jewel for a night on the town.
The way the light reflects off the back is very diamond like.
I think Amazon has the blue one on sale for $290.00 right now.
I'd like to help but I haven't had any of those phones :/

I returned the V20 after a week. While it was a good phone, I didn't like the UI. There was a crap ton of lag for simple processes like closing all your apps. The honor 8 hasn't lagged once for me at all. The camera is surprisingly nice on this phone. I thought the 1080 screen would be an issue, I can't tell a difference between this screen and my HTC 10 with a UHD screen. Battery life is awesome, you have 3 different built in modes performance, smart, and ultra battery saver. You can tweak the display color temperature to match what you like. 
For myself and many others the shinning star of this phone is EMUI. It is a hybrid UI of android with a touch of apple. It has a few quirks( which have been worked out in 5.0) it is the best user experience I have had with a phone. It's familiar yet completely different from any other android phone out there.

I use Nova Prime on my Android phones. I can't see that changing no matter what phone I use so the EMUI interface will only cover those things that Nova does not. ...settings menus and so on and that's just not enough to make or break a phone experience for me. I may give the 8 a shot because it's fun for me to experience different hardware but I'm pretty satisfied with my LG hardware.

I also cover every phone UI with Nova.
Nova is what I'm used to so that's the standard I like to keep.

I do the same. I keep reading about how much everyone loves EMUI which is awesome. I'm not sure what I'm missing by using Nova Prime. I don't like having more than one screen and do want an app drawer. I don't like multiple folders all over my screen like IOS or EMUI. I know you can hide unused apps in EMUI. This is off topic, but what am I missing out on by using Nova? I figured I wasn't missing anything really as I assume I'm still getting all of the features just not the look or skin if you will. Either way, I'd recommend an Honor 8 to anyone. I've gotten plenty of compliments at work and have not one person, in my small circle of friends/work mates that have ever heard of Honor. I tell them that it is just as good if not better than their phone for 1/3 of the price.

If you're used to nova, you're mainly just changing the gesture controls available to you, which you're probably more familiar with on nova anyway. 
When nougat and EMUI 5.0 rolls out in February, there is an app drawer available on EMUI.

replies.text: Congrats! What color is yours?
Decisions decisions, I too have an iPhone 7 plus and an Honor 8... debating if I sould sell the iPhone or hang on to it.

Well the iPhone won't drop much in price over the next few months so you have time.
I am in the same boat as you BTW.

I'm in a sort of same boat. I have a 6s Plus, and am looking at staying with Apple with the 7 Plus or going MUCH cheaper with the Honor 8. 
What do you think when comparing the Honor 8 to the iPhone 7 Plus?

Hi! I know you weren't asking me specifically, but I'll lend my two cents. 
I would find it a little bit difficult to truly compare the two, as the iPhone 7 Plus is a flagship device and the Honor 8 is a midrange device; however, the Honor 8 does have a lot of the similar specs of last year's average flagship at a great price. It is also somewhat similar in aesthetic to the iPhone line, in my opinion, but (also in my opinion), the Honor 8 looks better (also, I'm more of an Android fan). 
Also, if you're going to compare the two devices, if things like camera, video taping, etc are important to you, then the quality of photos/videos on the Honor 8 - though they're quite good - will not be on par with that of the iPhone 7 Plus.
The Honor and iPhone do have some similar OS components - like no app drawer, for example, and apparently their lock screen operations are similar? Again, I don't have any concrete experience with Apple, this is just what I've read and heard around the forums or with other users - but Honor does have a different operating system called EMUI, which has received mixed reviews.
If you're trying to save money and are interested in a unique and also budget-saving experience, I highly recommend the Honor 8. However, if you're really into Apple, are familiar with the OS, and enjoy the media aspect of the device, I would recommend Apple.
He's the perfect person to ask. If I'm not mistaken, he has both.

I think of Apple as a walled garden. Everything is great inside but if you want something outside of what's allowed then you are extremely limited unless you jailbreak. 
With that being said, the Honor 8 feels like 90% of the iPhone 7 Plus. Whether or not that extra 10% is worth twice the cost is up to you. 
I preferred the shots from the iPhone myself, but it wasn't a huge difference. The 2x optical zoom is nice but it is only effective in good lighting situations. Beyond that the camera will default to digital zoom. Daytime shots being very similar. Nighttime has a bigger difference.i posted a picture comparison here:https://www.google.com/amp/forums.an...?client=safari
Also remember that the Honor 8 is much smaller. On paper only 0.3" but in the hand, it is quite significant. 
iMessage is probably the biggest stickler for iPhone users as it isn't compatible with Android. 
I mentioned the iPhone 7 Plus a few times in my honor 8 review http://forums.androidcentral.com/hon...-8-review.html

The walled in garden is my biggest issue with Apple. I otherwise like it. Just hate that I can't set default apps and have to adhere to Apple's guidelines for everything. Like how I can't use speech dictation on any keyboard other than Apple's. I'm also firmly entrenched in Google's ecosystem (mail, calendar, music, movies, etc.). 
But I've been pretty much solely on iOS since December of last year. And now I'm starting to not think it's worth all the extra money when I can get an Honor 8 and Huawei Watch for half the price of an iPhone 7 Plus. It's a tough call right now. I may have to try it out. B&H has a good return policy.
Doo it! B&H really does, I deal with them very often and I have never been disappointed.

title: Little things about the Honor 8 software experience

thread.text: Anyone else think or realize just how unique the Honor 8 really is? It's the little details like one I just realized as I normally use a paid version app for my weather. Well the Honor 8's weather app is every bit just as good if not better than my paid version plus it's cool bc it plays a sound. Even down to the sound of rain if raining is out. Then there is the font size adjustment within a text by pinching or pull apart your fingers. Smaller or larger. I absolutely don't understand why I've read so many who dislike this software interface experience. It's not much of a learning curve and I personally think it's refined to a better experience than pure stock Android. Anyone else feel that way too? I'm about to place an order for a Moto Z Play as my second phone but I'm still highly considering ordering the Pearl Honor 8 in a 64g instead. I just wish they offered the honor 8 in two versions. 5.2 and a 5.5 or 5.7. I like for my second phone to be larger than my daily go to phone which is my black Honor 8. I'm not sure how EMUI 5.0 is as I haven't found anywhere that will allow me to download the beta version but if they have made it way more pure Android then I'm definitely staying on 4.1. I think this software is one of the best comparing to Apple iOS too out there.

I agree. It's amazing how much it adds everywhere, including the little things.
I have found myself missing some of that when I try another phone.
Honor really throws in a lot of features and customizations. It's perfect for those who like to tweak phones

I agree. It's done nicely and it's also refined and polished. Android to me has always appeared to kind of rough around the edges of that makes sense. Not sure if it's because I used Apple so long or what but the Honor 8 definitely has a refined type feeling software. Very unique in comparison to either hardcore Apple iOS and hardcore android.
The EMUI updates are more additions than taking away the features you like. You don't have to use the app drawer style homescreen and the 4.1 features are still there.

replies.text: In emui 4, you cannot use the app drawer without a third party app. In emui 5 you can use the app drawer as an option.

thread.text: I couldn't agree with you more, OP. EMUI is definitely not hard to get used to - in fact, I liked it the first day I booted up the phone. Depends where you are ordering it from. If you are ordering from B&H Photo, they will include a case and a gift box (which includes a selfie stick, usb-c cable, ac charge brick, along with a micro usb adapter). I don't know about Amazon but Honor does not include a screen protector.
There was a time when Amazon included a case with it, but I don't know if that's still happening or not. I believe Newegg includes some stuff too, but not sure. Ordering directly from Honor, you have no additional goodies I think.
tl;dr : my first statement answers your question.
Thx!
I think that it's more important to look at niceties or features that are inherent to the phone than items like case and screen protector. Just make sure you can get a case for the phone you choose.

title: Honor 8 Flashlight - Only one bulb activates

thread.text:
I've run into an interesting*bug with my Honor 8, and I was wondering if anyone*could confirm it.
When using the flashlight, only the top "cool" bulb seems to light up, and the other "warm" bulb doesn't seem to activate, even when taking pictures (although the latter is difficult for me to confirm with certainty).*This seems a bit wasteful and is a bit of an odd design choice - cheaper*phones like the Moto g4 have no problem with activating both flash bulbs when using the flashlight function, and this makes for a brighter flashlight overall.
This might sound a bit nitpicky, but I use the flashlight every day when navigating a dark campus, and the brighter the flashlight is, the better I am able to*avoid slipping on*cold New England ice or getting hit by a car (the former of which has happened, but thankfully not the latter). 
Can anyone confirm this issue, or*do I have a defective model? Please let me know in the comments below!

My 8 does the same.
It's very bright...

It's to save power as a flashlight. 
The warm bulb only activates as a flash dependent on white balance.
Ah, I see. Still, other phones use both, and the flashlight isn't used that often anyway (I mean*independently, photo flash is quite common)
It's a great decision. Means it lasts longer in an emergency

replies.text: Maybe an option to switch between both or one would be perfect, but that's probably in the territory of custom ROMs.
I imagine that it wouldn't be too difficult to implement.my iPhone has three brightness options.

title: Honor 8: One Month Later

thread.text:
After a month of using the Honor 8, I can absolutely back it up as a fantastic phone, especially at the $400 price point. While*there are plenty of other great options*in this price range, like the*OnePlus 3, the Honor 8 is still a powerful phone that holds up to daily usage.
As a student, I*need the best performance out of my phone, whether*I'm texting my friends, navigating with walking directions to a bookstore (for overpriced textbooks), or simply*lasting throughout a day of heavy usage, the Honor*8 fills all of those roles perfectly. The Huawei fast charging has definitely been a factor in this,*but*I*would still be comfortable with a day of heavy usage on battery only.
Pictures are also great on the Honor 8. While I still*look admiringly at photos taken with*a Samsung*Galaxy s7 or a Google Pixel, the Honor 8 camera has been great, and I feel*like the quality*has actually improved with the recent Nougat betas I've been testing (yes,*it's*coming, be patient). The dual cameras make for some great image quality, and I am able to capture sharp detail and accurate colors for daily posts*to Instagram.
The fingerprint sensor has seemed to slow down a bit, as is normal on most smartphones, but it is*still relatively snappy and continues to beat in contest the unlock times of phones like the iPhone 7 or even the OnePlus 3, much to my fellow tech-loving friends dismay.
All in all, the Honor 8*has held up well, and the upcoming Nougat update will definitely make it a lot nicer, and remove some of the bloat that came with*EMUI*4.1.*To the other Honor 8 owners, how has your Honor 8 been holding up? Let me know in the comments below!
May the Force be with you!
-Lumivalo
P.S. Yes, I did see Rogue One. I'm in a*Star Wars mood!

Excellent post, OP! I couldn't agree with you more. I've had my Honor 8 for less than two weeks, but I too am very satisfied with my decision and am still loving it! I love the fingerprint sensor and the fast charging - especially the fast charging. I'm really enjoying the EMUI experience, as well. Glad you are liking yours! And good luck with school! What colour did you get?
Yes, Star Wars was a great movie! I saw it with my boyfriend yesterday. Very well done.

I have had my Honor 8 for 1/4th of the year (whoa) and it's still been great for me. I have tried so many phones and it is just one of those that I have had no serious compromise with at all. No complaints at all, aside from wishing that it was shorter but that's not a real complaint
Yeah, I've had the Honor 8 just over a week now. Came from a G5. Very impressed.
Had the Honor 7 before as my second device besides the iPhone 7 Plus. Now I've bought the Honor 8 and am very impressed. Amazing speed and the sleek design makes my iPhone look really dated. :-D
I've got a good laptop and good tablet and still come back to my honor 8 for almost everything. It's such a joy to use.
I was at my local At&t store to get a replacement SIM for my second line, and the rep was asking me a lot about the Honor 8. He mentioned he gets tired of seeing nothing but Apple and Samsung.
Just wait a year or two. Then everybody will be talking about Huawei and not Samsung any more.

replies.text: I definitely feel like this line of devices will take off and be successful in some way. I also like using products that are "different" from everyone else's, so I love it when people ask, "what kind of phone is that?" I just like going against the grain.

title: Just found the perfect tempered glass, no halo at all

thread.text: Hello to all who are interested. I just lucked up and happen to order the perfect tempered glass for my new Honor 8. It has zero halo on it at all. I'll post a pick of the phone and package or link from Amazon shortly.
That's great news!
Here are the pics. This is a great one. The honor 8 in Blue I had before I could never find one totally without a halo. This one is perfect.
Maybe it's just me, but I see a halo.

replies.text: Absolutely no halo on this one. Here's three more pics. This glass is thinner than the others I used on my blue Honor 8. There's no halo. I actually just ordered another one to put up when this one needs replacing. You won't find one better than this if you are looking for a glass protector the doesn't show a halo I'm quite sure of.
Question how was the install easy or hard. To be honest I am usually quite terrible installing screen protectors but this seems to be quite a clean install

Very easy and clean. A tip or trick is first aligne the top hole cut outs at the top but don't press it down year. Gently lay the screen to rest on the surface of the device. From there with the tips of your fingernails slightly move to the perfect alignment. Just be sure you don't press at all bc once it starts to adhere then you won't be able to push anymore to get the perfect position. Once you are happy with your alignment, take a cloth starting from the bottom and start a normal wipe across back and forth as you move up the screen. If you have zero particles under the glass, it will adhere without any air pockets that particles cause. Even the smallest particle will cause an air bubble. I normally wipe my screen down with a solution and then dry it by whipping. Once you have the screen totally 100 percent free of Lent or particles, then at that point peel off your bottom layer of the glass protector. Have the phone turned sideways as this helps with the initial perfect hole alignment at the top. If you end up with naturally a bubble or air pocket either push it to the sides or tops or gently re-lift the protector until you get to the air pocket then release and proceed to wipe across and upward from there again. This may sound like a lot but once you start it takes less than a minute to install. The MAIN objective is to use good lighting bc I'm telling ya even the slightest lent or particle under the screen will show and myself personally, there is nothing worse than seeing something under the protector. That's why you peel the layer off last right before the install bc you run about a 95 percent rate of nothing jumping on the glass back layer to drive you insane. I install all of my own bc if you allow someone else to do it they will not care as much as you do. Attention to detail is a must die to alignment. Too much to one side can cause a halo also. It's really easy but I wanted to write this in detail to ensure you install perfect on your first attempt. Have some scocth tap near buy in case you do have a particle that gets trapped under as you can halfway lift it back up and slide the tape to the particle and snag it then lay it back down to finish up. Hope this helps man.

thread.text: That does look pretty good. I may have to consider this....
OK, maybe I'm thinking a halo is something different than everyone else. Can anyone post a picture of a halo on another protector?

replies.text: It's where the edges are delaminating.

None of that with this particular tempered glass. All the ones I had before with my original Honor 8 has the slight halo look. I really think it comes down to the less thicker glass on mine that eliminates the halo all together.

title: mind boggling....

thread.text:
When it comes to the environment your phone is in can it cause excessive battery drain. I can turn off mobile data and put my honor into ultra powered mode and after a few hours the battery has dropped 10+%. 
This literally only happens at my place of work. When I get home I am at 20% battery with 1:15 of sot. 
Yet when I am any where else like home I consistently get 4+ sot and still have 25+% battery.
Do you have a weak cell signal at work? What do you see on your battery stats, any process/app using an unusually high percentage?
Everything is normal. I haven't noticed poor signal. What about massive amounts of electrical equipment that is always on?
What about snr? You can have good signal but poor snr which can cause a significant battery drain

I agree, it is. I thought that my work signal was bad but I went somewhere tonight that was terrible! I was only there for like almost 3 hours and I went from 96 to 70%. In just 3 hours and my phone was warm for the first time ever

Are there wifi networks near your work that you can't connect to? There's a setting somewhere that always scans for open networks and if it's scanning networks and failing to connect in idle it will drain fast

I definitely agree that the environment in which the device is situated could cause significant drain. A good sign is noticing an improvement when you are home - making it stand to reason that the variable at fault here is the location of the device.

replies.text: No need to make it knock generations.

Congratulations, I'm also an adult. Back to your question. If you don't use social media, emailing images is a better option over mms as most email services don't compress them.
Is it possible that mms services have been updated between your use of each phone?

The POTUS has an official Twitter account. Every government agency has a Twitter account. Corporations have official Twitter, FB and Instagram accounts. Major news outlets use all 3 as well. Your statement makes zero sense. If you prefer not to use these platforms for personal reasons just say that. No need to make up a lame excuse.
You really took that deep.
Interesting. I guess I'll just use the stock messaging app until a fix arises.

thread.text: OK, better way to phrase this... Why did my S7 edge send excellent quality photos over MMS (Google messenger) and my Honor 8 does not? Both take very similar, excellent photos and both are on the same plan w T Mobile

replies.text: I tested your observation had not sent a picture through it does come out grainy interesting switched back to stock messenger took almost the same picture it wasn't grainy super strange.
Could be because T-Mobile supports advanced messaging (allowing higher limits for MMS) for the s7 edge, but not for phones that weren't purchased through them like the honor 8.

There are three limitations to file size for MMS. The carrier has a limit, the device has a limit and each app capable of sending the photo has a limit. The app limit can vary depending on which device it is on as well. Whichever is the smallest of those three values is the max size of file that will be sent.

thread.text: You really took that deep. Any fix for the issue?
That makes sense, but wouldn't explain why the stock messaging app is able to send higher quality photos.

replies.text: Because it is made by the same company that made the processor that does the compression.
Interesting. I guess I'll just use the stock messaging app until a fix arises.

thread.text: Actually, I just tested the stock messaging app and the pictures are still grainy, only a little bit better than using Google messenger. This is frustrating.

Yup, it isn't a T-Mobile issue either as I'm getting the same issue on ATT.
Photos are fine went sent through Whatapp, FB Messenger, etc, it's only through MMS that pics are sent low-res.
Perhaps with the Nougat and EMUI update this will be fixed.

replies.text:
It would still hold true with AT&T, because it also has advanced messaging through specific phones only. 
If I remember correctly the messaging app compresses the MMS files based on the service providers protocols. You may be able to get around it by downloading a third party messenger like Textra and changing the settings to no limit for files. However the MMS may not send and if it does the service provider will compress it anyway.

thread.text: I spoke with T-Mobile and it appears that the advanced messaging service is the issue. The honor is not compatible with this system as it is not a T-Mobile branded device. With advanced messaging you can send 15 mb and with standard MMS you are limited to just 1 mb. I'm guessing AT&T has a similar limit to their system and that is why you are experiencing the same issue. This is really a bummer. I love everything else about this device, but I may have to switch to something else if I cannot resolve somehow.

replies.text: Beat me to it lol. Should have refreshed.

thread.text: So this is a big deal for Honor 8 users! Every picture sent using SMS is grainy??
Yes, at least on T-Mobile and att. And I think just about every Honor 8 user in the US is on one of these 2 networks.

Good to know. I was thinking of buying a Honor 8 this Friday if the price was right. I'm using an Axon 7 now and liking it very much. The native ZTE SMS and email apps suck but those are easily replaced. I guess I'll hold off on the Honor 8. Texting pictures is a necessity.

Agreed, but sit tight. I'm testing Textra now as some have suggested and some fiddling with the settings in Textra may have solved the problem. I'll update soon. Also, I would think you'd have the same issue w the Axon 7 since it is an unlocked device and probably doesn't support advanced messaging.
I'm on ATT and haven't noticed any issues. I've used Google Messenger and Textra on the Axon 7. I'll check my wife's iPhone to see the pics on the other end.
Nope, not a problem. The pics I've sent to her iPhone look great.

Update: Using Textra with the correct settings works well. Still not perfect, but pretty good. Changed the Textra MMS settings to "carrier has no data limit" and chose "system" option over "legacy" option. Will test it further for the next few days and offer another opinion.

replies.text: That's good news. I do like Textra.

thread.text: Update #2: Totally disregard my previous note on Textra MMS settings. Apparently only T-Mobile customers would receive the MMS with those settings. Changed MMS settings to "carrier send limit 1MB" and "MMS behavior legacy" then enabled their T-Mobile WiFi fix. I just sent some photos to my step-dad on ATT and he said that they look crystal clear and no graininess. I guess Textra just does better job compressing the photos than Google messenger does. I'm liking Textra and will continue to use it until a fix arises for Google messenger.

replies.text: What mms settings are you referring to? I don't find any.

thread.text: In the Textra app, not in the phone settings. In the main landing for Textra click the triple dot in the top right and then select MMS

This is bad news. I'm on ATT and considering getting the Honor 8 today. I don't want to use Textra because of this alone. I'm happy with Google Messenger and need to text pics for work and plain convenience. Has this issue changed at all? Anyone on ATT with the EMUI 5/Nougat beta experiencing these issues?
I'm finding the EMUI 5 messenger really good.
I've personally never had a problem with MMS quality on ATT using the standard EMUI messenger. I tested quality back and forth with my work S5 which is on Verizon.

I'm with Cricket which uses ATT towers and I've not noticed any inferior picture quality when I've texted pics from my honor to my other phone which is a 6p. However I have had a one time only issue where my picture text failed and never sent through. Since then the very few pics I've sent to my 6p and vice verse both appeared to be of regular or typical quality. Perhaps it could be due to possibly a case by case type deal where at the time of sending the pic the reception or signal is low therefore it defaults to low quality to push the photo through? That could be totally a lame thought but I was just guessing at it. I alao read through the thread and noticed the social media tension of comments lol. I'm 41 and I use Facebook some and I use LinkedIn some too. Social media with today's technology is almost now a way of life if you are internet savvy. It's a common place for communication too. I'm not sure I understood why the negativity was implied over social media. Like all things in life it has its downfalls too. No one should fault anyone to be superior or inferior over the usage of communication platforms. To me this is a they are there if you choose to utilize them or not type deal. They all aren't set up for only young adults I personally don't think. Anyways I'm going to send some more picture texts and test the quality again. Now I'm curious what could cause some to be getting less quality photos than others.

I have this issue with Google Messenger on my Honor 8. I talked to a rep with ATT and she said it was not a carrier limitation. I will say though that the images I text look terrible. I'm not sure where to go with this. I guess I'll try the stock messaging app but from what I read that doesn't work well either.

title: Just realized this phone has an iPhone-like Control Center on the lock screen

thread.text:
Ha! I've had this phone for a week and a day now, and only just realized yesterday that it has a dock that's available from the bottom of the lock screen that gives you quick access to the voice recorder, calculator, flashlight and camera, in addition to the controls that allow you to work with the picture files that are displayed on the default "magazine"-style lock screen that the phone uses.
Definitely need to sit down and read the user manual I downloaded for this phone. I had thoroughly explored through all the Settings that are available through the phone's main Settings menu, but all of this stuff for the lock screen just doesn't exist there. It seems to only be accessible from this dock on the lock screen itself. :P

thread.text: It took me a while to find that too. I think I am going to follow you in your footsteps and download that manual.

Yeah, the thing that really surprises me about discovering this dock is that I read plenty of reviews and watched multiple videos about this phone before deciding to buy one and try it out for myself and I swear that not one of those reviews said boo about the lock screen dock. (Makes me wonder if any of the reviewers even knew about it). haha

iOS comes to Android

But the default launcher still isn't going to win me over and replace Nova. I can't live without my custom gesture commands, custom grid size and being able to swap out icon packs. haha

There is an app in the play store called EMUI theme editor. It lets you go in and change every aspect of the theme from notification bar icons to desktop icons. Change wallpapers and fonts.

title: Problem with incoming calls

thread.text: I use my phone for my company and when someone calls, the phone automatically pics up without my touching anything. I've had several people tell my they heard me talking or rustling around because I simply don't hear it before in answers the call!. I turned off all motion controls but I can't have this happen. Anyone know what's going on?

Hi! Hmm, that is a very strange and frustrating issue, I'm sorry! My suggestion to you is to do a test: have someone call you again and see what happens now that you have your settings updated. I think I saw something in settings about automatic answer or something along those lines - is that what you disabled? As a last resort, I'd try a factory reset (make sure everything is saved beforehand!). Please keep us updated on what's happening!
There is also a pocket touch protection option to stop accidental touches being registered, which is probably happening when the phone rings.
I haven't seen this problem myself but i would try the tips recommended above
I would normally supply screenshots detailing where to find the option, but the settings menu has had a major overhaul on the EMUI 5 beta so I am unable to at the moment.

Solved! Read a post from another board. There are two motion controls for "raise to ear to answer" one in motion controls and one under >advanced >accessibility. 
This one must be a Google feature? I think it uses the proximity sensor exclusively while the honor software uses both proximity and accelerometer. This setting does not work correctly! I'd have it in my pocket or just lying on a table and it would pick up on the first ring.

replies.text: So glad you got everything sorted out!!

title: How would you rate the Honor 8 on a scale of 1-10?

thread.text:
The title says it all - for the Honor 8 owners out there, how would you rate it on a scale of 1-10, and why?
For me, I've been pleasantly surprised. The phone is solid. Takes a beating, hardly any scratching or wear... EMUI has come a long way, the camera is decent, and that fingerprint sensor, yeah... so fast.
Overall I'd have to give it an 'Honor' score of '8'. How fitting!?

replies.text: I would say about 8.5 or 9... Still surprises me everyday fluidity of the OS, fingerprint, and I continue to get great spur of the moment shots
Agree with everything you've posted! I'm really loving the fingerprint scanner.

thread.text:
I think 8 will be my score 2.
Apart from QHD for VR and slightly louder dual speakers instead of the rather muted single one, there's not a lot missing from the package.

I can agree with the score of 8 as well.
The speaker is a quiet one, but it's generally an excellent deal in the many perks it has.

I would say 8 is fair for retail price, mainly because the competition is so stiff in this range and both the OnePlus 3 and Axon 7 have double the base internal memory for the same price. If you were to be able to get the 64gb for $224 during black Friday then that would easily be a 10.
I say depending what you paid for the phone...full retail $399 I would rate it a 7...Black Friday $250 I would rate it a 8.

I've been researching this device and it seems to be a solid phone and overall, a good choice if you're looking at midrange but flagship-esque quality (which the Honor 8 has in most areas) and a good bang for your buck. I'd say an eight out of ten is an accurate rating.

I have a HTC M9, A9 and Nexus 6P. From my perspective the Honor 8 is equal to the Midrange/flagship models and in many ways better. Build quality is superb. I like EMUI and really looking forward to the update 5.0. Only negative aspect is the lack of support for for CDMA carriers. I think a lot people would like to be able to pop a SIM into their Honor 8 for any of the USA carriers and the companies that resale there service. HUAWEI already sells the Union via Virgin Mobile. I give it a 9.
With EMUI 4.1, it was a solid 8, with EMUI 5, I have to say 9. It's smooth, fast, pleasant to view.

replies.text: Emui 5 is still beta so I based it off of official current software . The biggest problem with emui 5 is battery life bug and no icons in the notification bar though supposedly that is changing.

I haven't had battery life issues, not sure if lucky or doing something different. And the newest update brings back the icons for notifications, stock Android white as opposed to the colorful ones previously used.

I had battery life issues the first day or two. Then it seemed to fix itself. I am running in airplane mode with wifi on though so that could be something.
I noticed the icons in the latest update.... Limited to five plus overflow though when there is plenty of room. It is a move in the right direction though.

thread.text:
Mediocre battery life. Heavy UI layer causes occasional performance hiccups. Slippery, fingerprint-prone design.
So overall my rating: 7/10

replies.text: I am not sure if it is a UI issue... I noticed that it sometimes has hiccups when things are running in the background though. This phone tends to throttle pretty quickly compared to others that would get much hotter before throttling.

You must have a bad battery. My battery is the best I have seen. My phone is very fast with no performance problems. Try a case to counter the slippery fingerprint prone design. I have a IPAKY case that I got on eBay for $3.94 which included shipping and it provides excellent protection for the corners and back.

thread.text: So far I'd say an 8 leaning towards 9. What it does, it does very well. It's fast, smooth and beautifully made. From purely a performance standpoint, it is hard to beat it for the money. Fact is, it's hard to beat it period, even for more money. It's only downsides, from my standpoint, are the lack of an FM radio and no adoptable storage. And those aren't problems per se. They are design choices that I was aware of before I bought the phone. I haven't encountered any bugs yet which is a refreshing change from my previous phones. And nothing about the Honor 8 aggravates me either which is another breath of fresh air too. All in all, If Honor/Huawei can get good relationships with US carriers in place, they are poised to do very well with phones like this one.

On a 1 to 10 scale:
I rate this a "GO"

I've tested a lot of phones over the past year and half. When I say a lot like seriously over 10 devices. Some having had twice. Those were Samsung that I owned twice trying to force myself to like their software which is the worst on the high end market. The Honor 8 is easily equal to the iPhone 6s which used to be my favorite phone. I bought my Honor 8 for $349 and I should have waited and got it for $299 or went with the 64g. That being said and saying that it's equal to the 6s which is what $700 plus with 128g like I had, I'd rate this honor 8 an easy 8 plus or it may even pull in a 9 just barely. I have enjoyed Honor's software interface as it's a hybrid of Android and IOS which give the interface a smooth and seamless interaction. Performance is plenty good on this device and screen resolution is good too. I've not found one deal breaker on the Honor 8 and that's saying a lot going through as many phones as I have since leaving Apple last year. I can tell you I prefer the Honor over my Nexus 6p which is why the Honor is my main go to phone. I have two numbers so I keep two phones. At the moment I'm looking to replace my 6p with something else as I enjoy trying different devices. The Honor 8 is a keeper and it's refreshing and a nice change from typical Android and typical IOS. The 5.2 screen size can be debated but personally as a daily phone I wouldn't want anything any larger. I think they kept it 5.2 knowing that this size is as big as you can go if the device is to be practical for a daily driver. I know my 6p is hard to lug around and keep in my pocket. Personally my favorite size is 5.0 inches but the Honor 8 feels a lot like a 5.0 phone for some reason. For me to totally leave apple and to say this device is every bit as equal to the iPhone 6s is saying a lot from my point of view personally. I'm still a huge apple fan. No conpany makes a better tablet experience than apple hands down. Android phones that I think are great would be the Honor, Motorola and the Google line since Moto and Google keep it mostly pure Android. Samsung touch wiz is the worst choppy and sticky OK interface of all Android high ends. Anyways the honor 8 gets a 8 plus or a close 9 here for my vote. A big part of my vote was due to the software interface. There is simply nothibg on the market like EMUI and I'm one to promote different and unique. Honor 8 didn't follow a trend and made their software by using innovation and when I see or find that, I'm immediately a huge supporter. Being different and unique is who I am as long as it's done with taste and a lot of thought behind. You get that with the Honor 8.

replies.text:
Thank you for this amazing rate and review. I definitely agree with you. The Honor 8 seems to be very unique and appealing because, by nature, it is different from what's out there.
Also, I do like the 5.2" display. I've had 5.2" with the Nexus 5 and 5.5" with the LG G3; and I decided to go back a bit with ordering the Honor 8. I think 5.2" is a perfect size - sometimes, even a 5.5" device seems a little clunky to carry around! At least for me, anyway!
Also, you've got a good line-up of daily drivers there! The Nexus 6P is amazing!
It's just personal preference. My wife is using a 4" screen now and she doesn't want to use a larger screen.
Absolutely! It all boils down to what works for us, and what we like.

thread.text: Wow lots of great feedback here folks! Mostly ratings of 8 or 9! So good!

replies.text: ...and one "GO"

thread.text: I'll echo everyone and say 8. (Taking the price into account, I might say 9.5.) The only thing I realllllly wish were different is the speaker. Dual front facing speakers would be great. Better low light camera shots would be nice. Otherwise, no real complaints.
Price is an important factor... You should compare it to phones in its price range
^ Truth. What is the value for what you pay...

I would give it a 9. If the camera was as good as Note 5 or Galaxy S6, then I would've given it a 10. Seems like lots of people don't like the software, but I don't mind it. I like some of the native apps and features. Finger print scanner is amazing. Hardware is great. It's fast and the battery life has been pretty good. I have the white version and I think it looks great. The size is perfect for me. And for me, I love that it has onscreen buttons. I had the Note 5 and it was awesome, but I just couldn't stand the home button. I thought it was the size of the phone, but when I used Galaxy S6, I realized it was the home button that was bothering me. I think it has something to do with having to physically press down the button.
Anyways, I thought about getting a LG G5, but we know how reliable LG phones have been. I was able to purchase Honor 8 for the Black Friday pricing, so really, I should give it a 10.

replies.text:
I second you on liking the Honor 8 software. I cannot seem to understand why people don't enjoy this software. It's a very easy and seamless interface experience and it's a awesome change from stock or pure Android. 
Speaking of the color you mentioned you have. The Pearl White. Do you mind posting a pic of yours? I'm highly considering selling my 32g Black and getting the 64g Pearl White. I'm not for sure but I've hardly seen any live photos of this color in the Honor 8. What made you go with that color over the Midnight Black and Sapphire looking Blue. I've owned both the Blue and Black and I think the Blue in person slightly won out over the Midnight Black but by just a hair. I've not seen the Pearl color in person but knowing myself like I do, I would not be surprised of I just kept my Black and purchased a Pearl color version in a 32g too just to change up in a rotation type deal. I love everything about the Honor 8. Especially the stock software. It's the most enjoyable software I've yet to use. I just hope the 5.0 isn't too pure Android. I love things that are different and that don't follow conventional trends.
Here's some pics of my phone. I have a tempered glass protector and a skin on the back.
Where did you get your screen protector from?
It was a generic brand from ebay. Can't remember which seller.
Thank you!!

thread.text:
I officially change my rating to:
Major, major, major "GO"

Definitely a 9 for the price and the quality of the this phone. Have been use to using a Nexus 6 and Note 5, the only thing missing is Honor offering this phone in a 5.5" or 5.7" version with the same battery life as this phone. I guess the closest thing to that would be the new Mate 9 or Mate 9 Pro, but the prices of those 2 would change the value vs what you get for the money, very pleased with the Honor 8 no problems whatsoever after 2 months.

I can say with confidence I've had:
No crashing
No restarting
No lagging
No missed connections
No call drops
No wifi or data stops
No odd bugs
No issues with quality
Any small annoyance is easily overwhelmed by the best rounded experience the 8 provides.

I'll try to post some pics of the phone tomorrow. I thought the white stood out little more. I was a big fan of the Sony Xperia Z3 look and I thought Honor 8 was pretty close to it.
Yeah, I realized I'm not a big fan of stock android. Yes, you can download the apps, but sometimes, the native apps just work better. I've generally liked all the skins from HTC, Samsung and LG. When I used Moto X or Nexus, I always felt something was missing and had a hard time finding just the right app. I agree with you. I'm hoping the 5.0 isn't pure android. But I do like have an app drawer, so I like that they are adding that option.
Emui 5 isn't pure Android by any means.

I really love my Honor 8. I haven't been this happy with a phone since my Nexus 4 was new. 
EMUI is awesome, once you get used to the notification shade style, customize your themes and launcher, etc, I prefer it to the stock experience at this point. Huawei's feature set is among the best, and for the price you can't beat it. I wouldn't spend more on anything else that's on the market at the moment. This is why I give it a 10. You might find a slightly better processor, or a better camera, or a siri clone at twice the money... But when you factor in cost, is it worth it? I say no. This phone is not, in any way a compromise. The top of line phones on sale right now just aren't much better. If you're coming in from any top-tier phone from 1 or 2 years ago, this will be a big improvement. Even if you're coming from one of today's top-tier phones, you'd be amazed this was only half the cost...
Just my 2 cents, not "the best at everything". But anything more expensive than this is a ripoff.

Definitely give it an 8 or 9 rating out of 10. The package as whole is solid and the price is just good value. Not many short comings.. Even the software which so many complain about is actually not that bad. Really enjoying this device!
Probably 9 or even 10 as ive used WP for 5 years and last lumia 830 was horrid.

List higher range phones I in past yearish: 
1. Nexus 6p
2. Galaxy S6
3. Note 7(😥💣)
4. Honor 8
5. Pixel 
The Honor 8 compares VERY favorably within that group, no matter what category. Which is even more impressive given it costs $200-$550 less than those flagships.

title: Camera Shot in Low Light

thread.text:
I recently took a photo of my puppy in my living room and it came out looking darker than it really was in the room.
Should I have used the Night Shot mode instead?
Also, I noticed this photo looks even darker when I view it in the Photos app. I can barely see my dog. I even tried turning my screen brightness all the way up.
Thanks for any suggestions.
-Rich

Phone cameras in general suffer more indoors with low light than outdoors. I try to use the flash indoors. If I know it's going to be needed I set it to always on so the camera can adjust the white balance with the flash light already on the scene I'm shooting, much like red-eye reduction works.

thread.text: So besides the ability to pay for your Hamburgers, in your case a taco using your phone, what else are you going to miss from Samsung pay?

Best advise use what works best for you. Advantage of the honor 8 it's unlocked and only $300 atm. No carrier bloat ware. Not waiting on carriers for the latest updates(nougat beta has been going for a good month) we all know how timely Samsung is with updates. 
Battery life is good on this phone, it's snappy as hell. I have yet to experience any lag. If you want game and experience lag, you just adjust the power profile to performance and go. The ability to theme the UI from different user themes found all over Google plus and XDA. 
My favorite thing is EMUI. It's a nice fresh take on android. It has so many useful features added into and it's visually pleasing with the styles of animations it uses for different tasks. The programmable fingerprint scanner is very nice as well for extra gestures and quick launch options.

The Honor 8 is an impressive bundle for your buck, IMO. The dual-camera combo helps produce a better shot, and to quote Android Central, "It's quite capable of being your primary shooter." I've heard good and bad things about EMUI, but there are lots of themes and customizations available - or launchers - available to you for download if that's not your thing.
I've also heard good things about its battery life, and it has a good-sized display (5.2") if you're into that dimension bracket. 
Once my phone actually comes in the mail, I could give you more reasons lool, but these are just my impressions based on research and what I've seen around the forums. 
Also, this phone was featured in Android Central's Buyer's Guide (in the "Android Central Community" forum section). Now, obviously if you're coming from a Samsung product, your camera experience and flagship exposure is top-notch, but this phone, in my opinion, delivers a flagship (and unique) performance at a fraction of the cost.

title: Battery drain while idling

thread.text: I got the phone last week and I am noticing that the phone loses approximately 30% of the battery overnight without any usage at all. I had the same issue with a previous Honor 8 phone which I had to return. I am having the same issue with this one too. I would like to know whether anyone else is having the same issue or there is something wrong with the phone. Thanks!

Hi, there! Did this drainage happen with your previous phone when it was about a week old, as well? It could be that your phone battery is "adjusting," and it may take a few cycles for it to perform as it was meant to. However, if it experiences that kind of a drain overnight, I am not sure if that falls into this same category. How is everything else on the phone? Does it experience an unusual drain when you run apps like Facebook? I'd run a diagnostic of your battery usage over the course of a 24-hour period, and then see if any apps in particular are causing any significant drain while running in the background.

Hmm what apps are you allowing to run in the background?
I haven't experienced that at all, I lose maybe 3-5% overnight.

Hi Morty2264, Thanks for the answer. The issue for the previous phone as well as this phone are the same. From day 1 onwards they are having the same issue of losing 30-40 % battery overnight. I turned off the high usage apps like maps, FB etc but still losing lot of battery. I would have suspected there is something wrong with the phone except it is the second phone with the same issue. May be I have to play with the settings more etc?

replies.text: Perhaps you have to tinker with the settings. As libra89 mentioned, what is your cell coverage/signal like? If your phone has to search for a signal at any point in time, it will take a toll on the battery. Both my LG G3 and Nexus 5 have taken battery hits when signal coverage was low.

thread.text: Hi libra89. Thanks for the help. I agree that there lot of background apps. As I mentioned in the previous answer, I am cutting down all the non important apps but still I am having issues. I wonder whether I have to return this phone too!

replies.text: Hmm that's odd. How is your email sync? What power mode are you using? Performance or Smart? How's the connection (cellular + Wifi) in your area? Good, bad, OK?

thread.text: Like both of you suggested, the cellular signal in my area is spotty. I guess that might be one thing, I might have overlooked. I am using the smart power mode only.

replies.text: That could definitely be a cause, especially if both phones have experienced similar drainage issues. I'm sorry this is happening to you! But if you're using smart power mode and are Silvie diligent, I am sure things will work out. Does anyone else in your household experience a similar kind of drain?

thread.text: Thanks. We have different phones and I didn't notice any issues with their phone. That's why I am concerned. I am also baffled that two new phones are having the same issue.

replies.text: Yes, I can certainly understand why you'd be concerned. So, their phones are not draining a bit overnight? Hmm. What carrier are you with? I'm assuming you and your household are using the same carrier?

thread.text: Nope. Their phones are fine. Only the Honor 8 have this issue. We all are with Cricket. Thinking about it, the signal is not very bad either. Let me play with the settings and I will let you guys know how it went. Thanks and appreciate your time!

replies.text: Okay, tinker around with it and let us know what happens!

Good luck! I asked because at work, my battery drains quite a bit because the signal goes in and out for both WiFi and cellular. Even so, the Honor 8 has strong radios so it isn't as critical. 
If you have a moment, can you go to settings->apps->advanced settings->battery manager and tap the battery percentage and then let us know if you see a lot of red, yellow or green? Might be some orange too.
If you see a lot of red, this phone might not work so well for you in your area

thread.text:
For myself personally I was experiencing this at work when I am only using cell network. What I tried and seemed to improve my battery was going into settings under mobile operator and turning the mobile data always on option off. I have AT&T and cricket uses the same network. 
When I am at home and on wifi I get amazing battery life.

I would suggest turning off wifi+
The constant scanning hits the battery hard if your phone starts skipping between WiFi and cellular.

Thanks for all the suggestions. I turned off the wi-fi and deleted some unnecessary apps. I lost only about 6% of the battery overnight for the past couple of days. It seems to be a good range. I very much appreciate all your help in resolving this issue!

replies.text: Glad to hear that things improved!

title: My first day with the Honor 8

thread.text:
This is just a initial thoughts review, I've only had it for the day! 
I had a Samsung S7 but wasn't getting on with it so I sold it and had £350 to buy a new phone (around $400). I knew I'd lose some features like water resistance, camera and maybe performance but was happy to make the change for a phone which worked properly. 
I spend ages deciding on what phone I should get, more than is necessary really. It finally came down to the Oneplus 3 and Honor 8.
In the end I dismissed the op3 due to reports of poor signal reception and no expandable storage. I work in the countryside which weak signal, so decent signal reception abilities and expandable storage are a must (I've got 40+ gb of audio!). Also oneplus have a reputation of all but abandoning their older phones (though the op3 maybe different). I've seen what Huawei have done with emui 5 and while they're not necessarily the fastest they do seem to support a lot of their devices quite well! 
So we took the plunge and bought one yesterday. After the initial buyers remorse (I always get this, it's a phone for goodness sake!) I'm very impressed with what you get for the money. The screen is bright enough for me, has punchy colours (which I like), blacks are quite inky for a lcd and full HD is plenty sharp for me. I prefer amoled but this has its advantages (not worried about dark themes or the chance of burn in now, even if that isn't likely in this day and age). The s7 is a better display, but to massively to my eyes. I'm very happy with this. 
Performance has been great, I can't see the need to spend top dollar to get silky smooth performance anymore. It feels just as quick as the s7 (exynos version) in day to day use. I was worried about the graphics (kirin processors' weak spot historically) but I realised I don't play hugely demanding games and so far it's not skipped a beat. 
Battery is so far is great. Obviously it's to early to tell, with setting the phone up and downloading and updating everything but the battery percentage seems to take longer to go down.
Im actually fine with emui on the whole. The only two things I don't is no app draw and the icon appearance for some apps. So I've loaded nova launcher for now but applied for the emui 5 beta as that seems to sort the issues! 
Build quality is really nice. I would prefer a metal design but I use a case so doesn't make too much difference. I do think a case is essential though. The phone is slippery, in hand I don't have too much problem, but this phone slides of everything. I've put it on what I considered pretty flat surfaces and watched as it slowly tried to escape. I swear gravity has a stronger pull on it! I love the fingerprint scanner but keep pressing it (so used to the s7) and turning the torch on, but I'll learn! 
I'm enjoying the ir blaster, not had the opportunity to use the camera much so can't judge that yet. 
All in all, I got far more than I would for the money. I'm converted, no more 'flagships' for me I think. What you can get at this price point ticks most of my boxes and I'm looking forward to seeing how they improve on this in the years to come.
Welcome, sounds like you made the right choice for you.
Sounds like you made the right choice I agree on the lack of app drawer is different but you are using a different launcher. I am excited for emui 5 excited to see where the company is going
Yay welcome! It sounds really good for you.  What color is your Honor 8?

replies.text: Blue! I normally go for black phones as I find brighter colours too distracting. But this one is a nice mix, not too distracting but a little different to normal colour schemes.

thread.text: Glad that you liked it!
I love your review! Thank you for sharing! And a great colour to boot!

title: Honor 8 camera vs LG G4

thread.text:
Does anyone have real world experience with the Honor 8 camera vs the LG G4 camera? Especially in low light or fast moving scenes?
The G4 is a great phone but have had the dreaded bootloop multiple times which required warranty service. Being without a good phone during the repair time is very annoying so I'm looking to switch.

replies.text:
If we look at it from a technical point of view, the Honor 8 has a Dual 12 MP sensor with a f/2.2 aperture. Which should be fairly decent with low light photos. and since it has a 12mp sensor, the resolution is also quite good for cropping and zooming 
If we look at the LG G4. it has a 16 MP sensor with a f/1.8 aperture. So this means, your low light photos will be a fair bit better just simply because it can let more light in.
I would say yes the LG G4 might have a better camera in specs but when looking at the Honor 8 and the price you paying. You getting great value. I would give the Honor 8 a try. Its solidly build and i think you will be fairly impressed

thread.text:
I have and use both phones currently.
Many might disagree, yet I like the G4 camera quite a bit.
It's my go to camera when I want really good pictures or video.
I also enjoy the honor dual lens camera.
The honor camera is a lot of fun to use.
I'm still exploring it's features and I've had the honor for about 3 months now.
The honor camera will in no way disappoint any camera buff who likes features and options.
I can recommend the honor 8 wholeheartedly for picture taking in just about any light situation.
Thanks, I really appreciate your feedback!

All I can say is that the honor 8 camera has made me want to take more photos. It's such a joy that I look out for things to take photos of! 
The manual options in pro mode are fantastic to mess around with and simple enough to not put off beginners.

With low light and motion, the LG g4 takes a LONG time to take a picture. We are talking see several seconds here. Now if you want low light stills or well lighted motion shots then you would be OK.
I have used both, though not concurrently, and both cameras are great though from what I recall, the g4 is a little brighter in low light situations.
I've heard very good things about both cameras. Honor seemed to focus on camera improvements with this iteration, so I'm sure it will be good.

title: EMUI

thread.text: After using this phone for over 2 weeks, EMUI is now my favorite version of Android, I don't understand why so many people hate it.
I have to agree with you, I'm a fan. I like what it offers a lot.
The more I use it the more it is growing on me. If you haven't checked it out, go to the honor 8 XDA thread there are some awesome themes. My favorite so far is call deep blue.

Honestly, I think Huawei/Honor, LeEco, and some of these other riding Chinese OEM are on to something. Yeah purists deride them, but they add features thru their skin that add utility, and keep it to where it's familiar to a broad set of people. It may seem different at first, but the changes work. That's part of the great thing about Android.
Edit: of course, this is all matter of opinion.

I personally liked the stock Honor 8 software from day one. I've not even thought about using my Nova Pro launcher at all. The software on the Honor is a hybrid of both apple and Android and its interface is extremely seamless. I'm unsure why so many don't like it. I prefer it over stock pure Android any day.

replies.text: Probably familiarity ... Many people don't like change. For me the biggest issue was the lack of app drawer though emui 5 gives you that option.

thread.text: I got used to not having a drawer before the beta, but the beta made me realise how much I like having it. Haven't bothered with Nova since getting the honor though, so that shows how much EMUI has matured.

replies.text: The biggest convenience of nova for me is that it lets you backup home screens so setup on a new phone is quicker especially for people like me who go through lots of phones. Otherwise, emui 5 is perfectly fine as is for me.

thread.text: As other users have said, since EMUI is so different from Android in general, that is probably why they dislike it. However, like any new UI, launcher, etc, it takes a while to get used to, and then it can work great for you.

replies.text: I think you nailed it. It's a familiarity thing, not that one flavor is necessarily better or worse. It's finding the one that fits you.
Thank you! It is definitely a familiarity thing: we tend to go for what is known to us, and anythijg foreign to us as far as experiences go may cause us fear or uncertainty.

Go to battery settings then click the gear icon in the top right and you get this screen. Turn the prompt off.

thread.text: Started noticing that while the phone is plugged in to charge, the screen never totally turns off. It just dims, but I can still see the screen and bring it back to full brightness just by touching it. If I push the power button it cuts off as usual. I am running Nova Launcher on the latest version of the Beta that I downloaded yesterday.

I've been doing some more testing and the Android OS drain is still present. Somthing is keeping the system awake for long periods of time. I can confirm though that the problem is NOT with the beta build. I've set my system up on a Pixel XL and I'm getting the same issue. Its clearly a App running in the back ground. Going to spend the next few days and try and find out what app/apps are causing my issues.

The only real comparison would be running the same device on nougat and marshmallow with no extra apps installed and see which runs the battery down fastest. You'll probably find that the nougat stops other apps more than marshmallow and therefore the OS uses a higher percentage of power because other apps are using less.
Edit: check the mah being used and not the percentage.

OS 
Pokémon GO 
Percentages including hardware drain.
Just been reading a few Dev threads, and they suggest that the biggest problem lies with Google backup. Which can be turned off in settings.

Battery has massively improved. But my new issue is that now and then, the screen goes crazy and all these random "touches" happen, turning settings on/off and playing Havoc with whatever is on the screen on the time. A reset seems to solve it for a while, but sooner or later it comes back!

replies.text: That sounds like a hardware issue. Like there's water or dust getting behind the glass.

thread.text: It's never been near water. I'll see if it still happens once off the beta.

title: MMS picture quality Honor 8 AT&T

thread.text: Hello honor fans, quick question. How do I send pictures in full 12mp quality sent via text message mms? Every time I send a picture to anyone in my family the quality looks terrible, I really don't want to email them in order for them to see it. Almost everyone in my family has iPhones and I hate that I can't do something that so simple w iMessage. I really like the honor but for me this is a deal breaker, really I can't send a quality pic unless I use iMessage...

replies.text: I would look into the Textra app. You can adjust the files size for MMS to allow you send full resolution pictures.

thread.text:
Look at the details of the picture file. If the file is larger than 600KB, the MMS server is going to compress the picture - and that's always a hit on quality. Either compress them yourself in a way that makes them look good (there are a lot of different compression techniques - look in Play for apps) or take smaller pictures.
If they're already 600KB or smaller, send yourself a picture and look at it. If it looks okay, it's the recipient's phones. If not, call AT&T - I can't see how but it would be their problem (and everyone would probably be complaining about it).
I started a thread on this topic a couple weeks ago. Find that and you should get some help. Long story short, you may need to change messaging app and then fiddle with the compression settings.

title: Wide aperture mode in low light?

thread.text: Does the aperture mode provide any difference in low light images?
It has helped when I've used it.
I'm not sure, it's supposed to be a software effect, not a hardware feature

It has no effect, the lens is a fixed aperture so light can only be altered by the ISO settings and shutter speeds. The aperture mode is a software based and just blurs the background by combining the two lenses.

title: The screen is strong as hell...

thread.text:
Not something I had intended to test. My honor 8 accidentally flew out of my hand today and the screen hit the corner of my door frame as if I had thrown it in a rage. 
Needless to say, I panicked and thought it was done for. Not even a scratch, let alone a crack of any sort.
Wow.
This is amazing! I knew that phone was good but I had no idea it was also super strong!
I would say that you got lucky, since it was a single incident. Now if you could repeat it a few dozen times without damage, then that would be impressive.

replies.text: I would love to be able to test it and get more results but I wouldn't dare cause an impact like that on purpose Haha.
I certainly understand. Though in terms of scratch resistance, it is on par with other smartphones, assuming that it is the same strength glass as the p9.
Believe p9 uses gorilla glass, this has NEG Dinorex
Whatever it is, It's not scratch proof though... My screen unfortunately has some slight scratches.

That's interesting that they use two different screens. Just another reason as I stated in another thread about Honor 8 being different and unique and not following trend. What are the differences between these two screens if you don't mind sharing. Are comparable. I've of course heard of the first but the latter Im not familiar with. 
OP that's awesome you didn't crack your Honor considering it looks like it's made to crack being that it's just a solid piece of slippery glass lol. Glad you avoided a nightmare man.

thread.text: I agree about the screen. I dropped my phone 4 times from about 3 feet. Not that I'm clumsy, but rather a slippery phone mixed with a short charging cable equals a fall from my night stand lol. I've since used a longer cord to avoid these incidents. :/

NEG is nippon electric glass. 
There are some good demonstrations on their website regarding Dinorex. From what I have gathered watching them, the main difference is that this glass is flexible as well as being very hard so has increased shock resistance. Probably slightly less scratch resistant than gorilla though.

replies.text: Thanks brother for the info on the the two screens. I'm thinking the second screen that is flexible sounds do be the better of the two simply for impact reasons. I good screen protector or tempered glass would cover you on avoiding any scratches.
Interesting, thanks for doing the research

title: Double Tap to wake?

I have tried several apps but none seems to work or stick (works then turns itself off) with my current configuration. Does anyone have any recommendations to allow this functionality?

You will need to whitelist the app with the gesture function and allow it to ignore optimisations so that it doesn't get killed when the screen is off.

thread.text: Whitelisting/ignoring optimisation options for apps are in the battery menu.

Protected to make sure they always work.

thread.text: Hmmmmm

Hi James, on it's own the Honor 8 fingerprint sensor should never slow down with use. If someone does experience an issue with their fingerprint sensor, here are some common causes and solutions.(DM)CausesYou touched the sensor while charging your phone with a third-party charger.There is dirt or grease on the fingerprint sensor.Your finger is too dry, or your skin is peeling or damaged.You placed your fingernail on the fingerprint sensor.SolutionsUse the charger that came with your phone to ensure that the fingerprint sensor works properly when your phone is charging.Keep your fingers clean to ensure that the fingerprint sensor can recognize your fingerprint.You may need to apply more pressure during cold weather. If the fingerprint sensor still fails to recognize your fingerprint, try blowing onto your fingers, or washing your hands and then wiping them dry.Try using another finger and prevent your skin from becoming too dry, as this may affect recognition accuracy.Remove, then re-add your fingerprint, ensuring that you record different parts of your finger to improve recognition accuracy.Ensure that your finger covers as much of the fingerprint sensor as possible.
Thanks for the tips!

replies.text:
If it helps, for me I found it easier to go to the thread I linked on my Honor 8 using CHROME, and download the font I want. Then I would go into the Files app->Local tab->Internal Storage->Download
Select the file and tap menu. You will see the option of "rename". Rename the file type from .zip to .hwt. You'll probably have to move the cursor to be able to select the zip part. A warning will pop up, select OK, and then select it again. Tap the move button and select the folder you want to move it to (in this case, HWThemes). Tap "Move" again to drop the font in there. That's it, but I'm going to make another post of visuals to help you see where you might have went wrong.

thread.text:
@Dconn1975 , check this out:
Tap Local when opening the Files app
Go to Download folder,select the font and tap Menu button
Choose Rename in the menu options
Move the cursor to .zip
Change it to .hwt
Press OK
Select the font again and tap Move
This pops up; move is underlined to note that this is what you are doing
Tap Internal Storage, scroll down to HWThemes and tap it
Tap Move to paste it there
It should be in the folder now, you're all done!

title: First 5 things you do with your Honor 8?

thread.text:
I am tracking my newegg order (Canadian!) and hope to have the black Honor 8 in my hands sometime next week!
What are the first 5 things I should do? (coming from a 2013 Moto X)
Thanks!
I usually install Nova on any Android I use

I would suggest the following:
-Settings->Advanced settings->battery manager and then protected apps to make sure you get notifications from the apps you want to get them from.
-Change your icons around for the shortcut shade. You'll be glad that you did.
-Also when you put it down on a table, put it on something with texture. This phone is slippery and will slide off the table easily.

replies.text: What do you mean by "Shortcut shade"?

I mean this. You get it whenever you pull from the top. 
Also speaking of that, you can change the layout of the buttons, too. You can try them out or change them. Personally, I like the regular layout with the button to see all of your notifications, added. That is the fourth button on my screenshot here.
Can you change it so that the button on the bottom right pulls down your notifications, and if you actually pull down from the top it goes straight to the shortcuts? that would be sweet!

Yeah, it automatically does that if you have no notifications. Since I have no notifications, it did that without any work from me. If you do have notifications, it will go to the notifications automatically, regardless of the button or pulling from the top.

thread.text: Whitelist your apps.

replies.text: Definitely. Especially if you use a third party alarm clock.

What you mean by Whitelist your apps? 
Thanks
Settings, advanced settings, battery manager, protected apps.

thread.text:
As others have already said, definitely go into the Battery settings and protect any apps that you don't want killed in the background/that you want to receive notifications for. The default power settings on this phone are very aggressive about killing open apps to extend battery life.
If you want a more "stock Android" look for this phone, you can install the "stockify" theme for free from the Play Store: https://play.google.com/store/apps/d...theme.stockify
Setup whatever custom actions you want to assign to the fingerprint button on the back of the phone. (Honor calls it the "smart key").
Set your SD card as the "default location" in the Memory & Storage settings, if you want the phone to use the SD card as the default place to save things.
Enable "Remaining Battery Percentage" in the Battery Manager settings if you'd like the battery percentage to appear in the Notifications Bar.
Swipe up on the lock screen to access the dock located there for quick access to a few pre-selected apps and to customize the wallpapers that are shown and cycled through by the "Magazine"-style lock screen.
I set up my honor 8 with data turned off to begin with and went through the settings menu one by one and uninstalled apps I didn't want before getting started with accounts.

1. Launcher
2. Emui theme
3. Wave unlock app
4. Next lock screen
5. Arrange home screen
Then you can worry about your whitelist and power settings etc. Emui is an excellent OS, huawei launcher is not for me. Neither is the stock theme. Stock lock screen isn't ideal either. Fix the annoying things first so you can enjoy the phone. 
Have fun, I think you'll love it!

title: Positively or negatively, what makes your Honor 8 better than other Android phones?

thread.text: Given Android version, UI, or just why you like, or dislike, the Honor 8, would you recommend it to new or returning Android users? How does the Honor 8 stack up against, say, the new Pixel or Pixel XL?

Cost, size, and performance.

replies.text: Exactly what I was going to say. Love the sapphire blue color also.

thread.text:
I just recieved the black version and it's gorgeous! I have tried 3 of the smallest android phones in the last couple months. The pixel, sony xperia x compact and the Honor 8. 
The pixel was the smoothest (and most expensive) unfortunately, Bluetooth is not functioning correctly with my car
The X compact is surprisingly fast and smooth but I can't get over the screen quality which is subpar and the Camara leaves something to be desired. 
Anyway, the reason I'm going to finally stick with the H8 is because the phone is a perfect size imo, the screen is beautiful, the phone is fast, the Camara is great, and the fingerprint scanner is the best on the market. Also, I can't say enough about having an ir blaster, especially if you have several TV's!
I also notice that honor seems to care about this line and I anticipate it getting regular updates as I look forward to next year's model.
Negatives would be video quality and emui 4.1 takes getting use to but waiting for 5.0 and nougat gives my something to look forward too.
Excellent bang for the buck. Flagship level performance at a mid level price. Hard to beat that.
I will keep my s7e. But this phone is great for the price

I've got the Nexus 6p also as my second phone and number. It's really hard to find a device to compare to the Honor 8. 6p and Pixel XL definitely are comparable to each other. Honor takes Android and to me personally knowing apple as well as I do having only used their product since breaking my blackberry addiction around the iPhone 4 and 5 time period, that the Honor 8's software interface is a hybrid of both apple OS and Android. I've tried a lot of android out this year for the first time and the Honor is just different. I actually like the interface more so than pure Android. So comparing it to a stock Android is hard. I've yet to own or handle anything that is similar. That being said, I like different and I like unique so it may not appeal to everyone. It seems from my research that one either loves EMUI or hates it and downloads a Android interface launcher. I've not altered my Honor 8 any. I love the software. I just hope they keep innovating as that is what creates and inspires. If they lay off and not stay on their game then I could see the Honor line hurting or failing. As long as they keep it rolling and stay their high expectation course then the Honor will always have its place as one of the best devices vs value.

Being a apple only user for many years until about a year ago that the hybrid of the two softwares IOS and Android that the 4.1 offers is cool to me. So if I choose not to upgrade to 5.0, I'm sure that means I'll loose the security patch too. I guess I'll have no choice. I dig 4.1.
